statement.text: Chronic mesenteric ischemia presents with the classic triad of postprandial abdominal pain (intestinal angina), food fear (sitophobia), and unintentional weight loss, resulting from inadequate blood flow to meet the increased metabolic demand of digestion.
statement.formal: CMI Triad: Postprandial pain + Food fear + Weight loss = Classic presentation (but triad present in only 50-75%)

explanation.intuition: Think of CMI like cardiac angina, but for the intestines. Just as heart angina occurs when blood flow to the heart cannot meet the demands of exertion, intestinal angina occurs when blood flow to the intestines cannot meet the demands of digestion. Eating becomes exercise for the gut - and just as a patient with angina avoids stairs, a patient with CMI avoids eating.
explanation.key_insight: The pathognomonic feature is the relationship between eating and pain. Unlike most GI disorders where people feel better after eating, CMI patients feel worse. They learn to avoid eating to avoid pain - leading to profound weight loss and the characteristic 'food fear' or sitophobia.

postprandial_pain.mechanism: Increased metabolic demand exceeds blood supply

food_fear.description: Fear of eating due to anticipated pain
food_fear.behavioral: Patients may not recognize or report this pattern

weight_loss.mechanism: Reduced intake due to food fear

classic_triad.triad_prevalence: Complete triad present in only 50-75% of patients

other_symptoms.diarrhea: Due to malabsorption in some cases
other_symptoms.constipation: May occur due to reduced intake

vascular.trophic_changes: May have signs of PAD in extremities

frequently_confused_with.distinguishing: Pain may be more constant, history of alcohol/gallstones
May have similar presentation - imaging key

differential_diagnosis.diagnostic_workup: Often extensive before CMI is considered

progression_to_AMI.risk: 20-50% will progress to acute mesenteric ischemia
progression_to_AMI.implication: CMI is a pre-lethal condition requiring treatment

sources.citation: Defined review on chronic mesenteric ischemia presentation
SVS guidelines on chronic mesenteric ischemia

learning_objectives: Recognize the classic triad of chronic mesenteric ischemia
Understand the pathophysiology of postprandial pain
Differentiate CMI from other GI disorders
Appreciate the natural history and risk of progression to AMI
clinical_pearls: Think CMI: elderly + weight loss + postprandial pain + atherosclerosis risk factors
Abdominal bruit is present in most but not pathognomonic
The triad is classic but not always present
CMI is a pre-AMI condition - treat before disaster strikes
